source.author: Hunter, J.T.; Bruhl, J.J.
source.title: Phyllanthus
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae
source.citation: From: Hunter, J.T.; Bruhl, J.J. (1999). Phyllanthus. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Herbaceous summer annual; weed of urban gardens
Native plants; mostly Woody perennials, or, if ever annual and herbaceous, confined to far north-west Victoria.
Shrubs; stipules red, red-brown to black; not in far north-west
Herbs (or weak subshrubs); stipules cream to yellow-brown; far north-west only
Plants to 0.5 (–1.2) m high; leaves 1–7 mm wide; female pedicel in fruit 1.5–3.5 mm long; styles variously divided
Plants usually more than 1 m high; leaves 4–20 mm wide; female pedicel in fruit 2.5–8.5 mm long; styles undivided
Branchlets smooth, minutely serrate to papillose; leaves flat, not paler below, glabrous to papillate; male sepals red (when fresh); filaments free; female flowers 1 per axil
Branchlets scabrous to hirsute; leaves concave, paler below, scabrous to hirsute; male sepals white to yellow (when fresh); filaments connate; female flowers 1–2 per axil
Plants monoecious or rarely dioecious; leaves flat, glabrous; male flowers 1–21 per axil; male pedicel 2–6 mm long; female flowers 1–4 per axil; styles 0.4–1.5 mm long
Plants strictly dioecious; leaves concave to convex, rarely flat, densely papillate; male flowers 2–10 per axil; male pedicel 1–4 mm long; female flowers only 1 per axil; styles 1.2–2.4 mm long
Seed striate, more or less flat-sided; branchlets ellipsoid to flattened in section; at least some leaves subtending branches reduced to stipule-like scales
Seed rugose and ribbed, prominently pitted on one side; branchlets rounded or sometimes ellipsoid in section; leaves subtending branches not reduced (but lower leaves often deciduous)
